. 

It is the largest city on the Turkish Black Sea coast.
Samsun has a special place in the republican history of Turkey, as this is where the republic's founder, Kemal Atatürk, set foot to start the War of Independence in 1919.

value: content= There are frequent flights from
, daily from other big Turkish cities and some international (mainly from Germany) flights in summer.
alt=Samsun Yusuf Ziya Yılmaz Şehirlerarası Otobüs Terminali, Samsun Otogarı
content=Buses are a cheaper and slower alternative than plane, particularly if you're not coming from Ankara or Istanbul.
content=Samsun also has a railway connection with the
, with passenger trains plying the route between Samsun and

back and forth. As with the rest of Turkey, this is both the slowest and cheapest alternative, though also the most comfortable, as trains are equipped with spacious seats, usually mostly empty, and equipped with outlets and toilets.

The city has a network of trams, buses,

es, and taxis.

The city travelcard is called Samkart and can be bought at the main tram stops.

The very modern tramway, with its 21 stations all along the city between its terminii of
(mainline train station) and University stations, is possibly the most useful option.
are much more frequent than buses - you can always ask the driver details on where to get off, etc.

value: content=This is the replica of the ferry that took Kemal Atatürk from Istanbul to the port of Samsun. Inside, there is a collection of photographs of Atatürk and his comrades. You can also watch a short film.

content= Walking from the bottom of 19 Mayis Blv towards the sea you can see life size models of historical figures; and Atatürk and his comrades alighting from another, partial, replica of the Bandırma at the sea front.
directions= From the city centre take either number 1 (red) dolmus west to its last stop or tram to Baruthane: then walk up. Alternatively take the cable car from Batı Park.
content= offers a sea view, Hellanistic era tombs, and cafes in pleasant grounds.

content=this is the delta plain of Turkey's longest river (1355 km source to sea), Kızılırmak (literally "red river", due to its colour). The delta is great for birdwatching (320 species of birds call there home) as well as for fishing.
directions=Çay Mahallesi in Çarşamba, a town a little further east (~30 km),
content= One of the rare wooden mosques in Turkey, this one dates back to 1206, and its construction does not involve even a single nail (all wooden plates were inserted through each other).

content= is a witness to Atatürk's activities while in Samsun. The collection includes some clothes and personal paraphernalia, purportedly belonging to him. It also includes a number of old photographs and maps.
content= is dedicated to local history and artifacts, including the golden Amisos Treasure.
content=So new the tobacco still smells good.

. For a city of half a million there are very few foreigners: so most people will be happy to chat if you want to. Try the sea front, parks or outdoor cafes. No need to feel lonely if you are travelling on your own: just ask one of the many English language schools if their students need any conversation practice - especially if you are a native English speaker they will welcome you with open arms.
— Good for walking or cycling, or you can take a ride in a horse drawn carriage.
. A trip along the coast which takes 2 hours, on a boat named

In summer locals love to barbeque in the big parks and drink tea from samovars.

content=There are a lot of trees, basketball and football areas and a lot of cafes. From here you could walk up the River Mert.
directions= Take dolmus or tram to Baruthane.
content=— Big, with plenty of kitsch. Also by the sea but the trees have not had much time to grow yet.
. If you are interested in arts, you will find a thing or two that you might like. There is a very large and interesting opera building with weekly shows.
. There is a go kart course in Batıpark (West Park)
. The Black Sea is rich in fish varieties.
. There is a course in town.
. There is a paintball ground in the locality known as Körfez, somewhat far from city centre.
. In summer water skiiers are towed around by an overhead circuit, near Dogupark (East Park)
. Two festivals are celebrated annually in the city. Some competitions are held during the
. On the other hand, concerts of popular singers are to be found during the
, one of the local universities). Both festivals are usually celebrated around the end of June.

is one of Samsun's delicious 'events' and has four different types available
(Turkish wurst&egg) although there are some further varieties also possible such as spinach,

etc.

The local people all eat
s are totally unique to the city, so don't expect to find them anywhere else.

content=Eat traditional food, drink Ottoman sherbert and talk about all the old stuff.

TTNET Wi-Fi at the airport is slower than the local tortoises.
Internet cafes usually cost 1 lira/hour, but they're quite slow.
Internet in hotels is also quite slow.

directions=SW 90 km - 3 hrs by train or 2 by coach, Train (7.5 TL single) is the nicest way to travel there: after leaving the outskirts of Samsun in the morning the first hour of the journey is the most scenic; peach orchards followed by a steep green river valley. The train is comfortable with plenty of space: but bring your own snacks or drinks as none are served.

content=— with its seaside view badly ruined by the Black Sea Highway, is still an important historical city, that is great fun to explore. The main city of the northeast has a lot to offer a visitor, and is the place to stay when traveling to the stunning Sümela Monastery. Take a tour to Lake Uzungöl
